I am convinced a pretty neat theme can be created.

am totally bored with 100% Holo and pure card layout) and other developers
should bring their own branding.

I also don't think that trying to emulate elevation and motion is a great
idea, as the performance ill be poor.

As a conclusion, I strongly believe something can be done easily to bring a
basic but still "better than holo" working Material theme.

MaterialEverywhere?
MaterialCompat?

From here : https://developer.android.com/preview/material/theme.html
_Note:_ The material theme is only available in the Android L Developer
Preview. For more information, see Compatibility
https://developer.android.com/preview/material/compatibility.html.

And the link :
The material theme is only available in the Android L Developer Preview. To
configure your app to use the material theme on devices running the Android
L Developer Preview and an older theme on devices running earlier versions
of Android:

Define a theme that inherits from an older theme (like Holo)
in res/values/styles.xml.Define a theme with the same name that inherits
from the material theme in res/values-v21/styles.xml.Set this theme as your
app's theme in the manifest file.

_Note:_ If you do not provide an alternative theme in this manner, your app
will not run on earlier versions of Android

By the way, I totaly agree : let's forget 2.x and focus on API 14

from the material theme in res/values-v21/styles.xml.Set this theme as your

bartoszgadzala:
Hi,

Maven is a project management tool - http://maven.apache.org/what-is-maven.html. It handles (among other things) dependency resolution. In maven each artifact is stored in maven repository (http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-repositories.html). Many Android libraries (for example ActionBarSherlock) are available as maven artifacts which allows to consume them in projects which are maven driven.

To mavenize project you will need to add pom.xml (Project Object Model) which holds all project metadata. If I'll find some free time, I'll try to create apropriate pom.xml and send you a pull request.

Best regards
Bartek
. You can upload it to Sonatype OSSRH - more details at https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide. According to documentation, they're requiring a 'licenses' element (see http://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Licenses for details ), but it should be trivial to add it. I hope it will be helpfull.
. Hi,

any news or problems in which we can help?
. Additinally I've changed .gitignore to ignore target directory where Maven creates files while building.
. Hi Aleksey, can you explain why do You want to remove project.properties? In my opinion (which can be wrong - I'm not quite sure and that's why I'm asking) project.propeties should be fixed to something like this:

```
target=android-15
android.library=true
android.library.reference.1=../contrib/ActionBarSherlock/library
```

and then new submodule contrib/ActionBarSherlock should be added to HoloEverywhere. In that way, we don't have to modify project.properties to fix reference to ABS library and Eclipse will not complain about missing project.properties while importing the project.

I've already created a pull request (see  Issue #29), but then I've found Your issue report which forced me to think that I may be wrong.
. Thanks for the response.
1. HoloEverywhere already depends on ABS (in Theme.HoloEverywhereDark.Sherlock for example) so it's not possible to don't use ABS right now. Maybe the real problem is a dependency on ABS and HoloEverywhere should be divided into
   a) pure HoloEverywhere without Theme.*.Sherlock, and
   b) HoloEverywhereABS with action bar stylings
   In that way user can use HoloEverywhere with or without ABS.

2.You are right, thanks for pointing that.
. Hi Christophe, You can read abou Git submodules at: http://git-scm.com/book/en/Git-Tools-Submodules. You can check how it works on my fork by simple:

```
git clone https://github.com/bartoszgadzala/HoloEverywhere.git
cd HoloEverywhere
git submodule init
git submodule update
```

which will clone HoloEverywhere, initialize submodule and download ABS sources to contrib/ActionBarSherlock.

Result will be:
- HoloEverywhere
  - HoloDemo can be imported in Eclipse by Import existing project
  - HoloEverywhereLib can by imported in Eclipse by Import existing project
  - contrib/ActionBarSherlock can by imported in Eclipse by New wizard and select Existing source

It would be very simillar to current situation, except the fact that we won't depend on users specific location but using internal submodule. I hope I've  explained it clearly :)
. After merging that, You can close #14

I believe (at least in my case) that the `FontLoader` is throwing an error "Error: native typeface cannot be made" which I guess is quietly breaking the `EditText`. The styling of the `EditText` comes from the theme so, as long as your application/activity is from one of the HoloEverywhere themes the `EditText` will look right. The `EditTextHolo` and other "Holo" classes try to load the Roboto typeface in as the typeface.

. @zuecho The HoloEverywhere `Activity` class is programmed to throw that error when the `Application` class doesn't extend `org.holoeverywhere.app.Application`  (probably because it depends on the code in that class being executed to work properly). This means you can either implement an application class that extends that class, **OR** you can simply follow the recommendation and add '`android:name="org.holoeverywhere.app.Application"`' to your `<application>` tag in the AndroidManifest.xml. The problem is that the default Android framework `Application` doesn't execute the proper HoloEverywhere code to allow the HoloEverywhere `Activity` to work.

@Prototik maybe the error should say "or use a class that extends org.holoeverywhere.app.Application".
. @Prototik I sent this toward Robolectric, but are you saying that those things should be done in our code, or changed in Robolectric? I don't completely follow your sentences.

. I was just looking at this issue myself. Did you check the logs? I believe (at least in my case) that the `FontLoader` is throwing an error "Error: native typeface cannot be made" which I guess is quietly breaking the `EditText`. The styling of the `EditText` comes from the theme so, as long as your application/activity is from one of the HoloEverywhere themes the `EditText` will look right. The `EditTextHolo` and other "Holo" classes try to load the Roboto typeface in as the typeface.

``` bash
            <dependency>
                <groupId>com.github.christopheversieux</groupId>
                <artifactId>holoeverywhere-library</artifactId>
                <version>${holoeverywhere-library.version}</version>

. See demo. setForceThemeApply in Activity, ThemeManager.modifyDefaultTheme, ThemeManager.modify for all themes used in ThemeManager. And sure restartWith(Dark/Light/LightWithDarkActionBar)Theme. But it's restart, don't call it in onCreate.
. And Application.getConfig().setAlwaysUseParentTheme/setUseThemeManager
. Let's start by defining: you need to set a theme on Activity or on all application?
If first: is not satisfied setTheme?
If second: then yes, you should use ThemeManager. But does not enable the everything, in the hope that everything will work out.

`Application.getConfig().setUseThemeManager(true).setAlwaysUseParentTheme(true);` - as static block in your application class.

`ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.DARK)` Or LIGHT, LIGHT_WITH_DARK_ACTION_BAR. There also.
`ThemeManager.modify(ThemeManager.FULLSCREEN)` - if you want full screen theme.
`ThemeManager.modify(ThemeManager.NO_ACTION_BAR)` - and if you want theme without action bar.

On launcher activity you should set @Holo annotation with attr forceThemeApply = true, or call setForceThemeApply(true) before call super.onCreate.

For restart activity with new theme use ThemeManager.restartWith***Theme.
. With custom themes you should allow them to use. `ThemeManager.setOnlyBaseThemes(false)` before setting any themes.
. Application sample with using custom themes: [download](http://ubuntuone.com/3xNlkx4ozSHnVOSOkIlJUZ)
. About ListPreference: use getSupportSharedPreferences (or getDefaultPreferences), will be reverted to getSharedPreferences in next release.

. Yes, I think a little clarification of the situation can not hurt.

`DialogFragment.show(FragmentManager, String)` and `DialogFragment.show(FragmentTransaction, String)` is deprecated because there were problems at 2.1-2.3 on restore instance state when tag == null. New methods simply generate tag name from class name and it's hashcode. But this methods also suggest that each DialogFragment's based class at any time will not be more than one instance. If this bothers you - you can use the old methods, it will not be deleted ever. But I recommend to use new methods, just in case ;)

You should create custom theme extends from Holo.PreferenceTheme and Holo.PreferenceTheme.Light and remap Preference themes on yours:

``` xml
<style name="CustomPreferenceTheme" parent="Holo.PreferenceTheme">
  <item name="checkBoxPreferenceStyle">@style/CustomPreferenceCheckBox</item>
</style>
<style name="CustomPreferenceTheme.Light" parent="Holo.PreferenceTheme.Light">
  <item name="checkBoxPreferenceStyle">@style/CustomPreferenceCheckBox</item>
</style>
```

In static code block of your `Application` class:

``` java
PreferenceInit.map(R.style.CustomPreferenceTheme, R.style.CustomPreferenceTheme_Light);
```
. Show code. 
. You are specify theme in manifest. When theme manager resolve activity theme and try to determine color scheme (dark/light/mixed), it's cannot resolve it. And it apply default PreferenceTheme - Dark.
Use ThemeManager: 

You can apply theme before onCreate:

``` java
setTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);
super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
```

Or define default application theme in Application class:

``` java
public class MyApplication extends org.holoeverywhere.app.Application {
  static {
    ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);
  }
}
```

. It's problems in implementation of SlidingMenu. In demo using next code for disable saving of opened state after change of theme:

``` java
    @Override
    protected void onPostCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        savedInstanceState = instanceState(savedInstanceState);
        if (mCreatedByThemeManager && savedInstanceState != null) {
            savedInstanceState.putBoolean("SlidingActivityHelper.open", false);
            savedInstanceState.putBoolean("SlidingActivityHelper.secondary", false);
        }
        super.onPostCreate(savedInstanceState);
    }
```

You can put any custom condition instead `mCreatedByThemeManager && savedInstanceState != null`, for example, check on landscape orientation.

. onSearchRequested(), startSearch(), triggerSearch() and other don't supported by HoloEverywhere or ActionBarSherlock. You should change a behavior for correct handling of search feature.

Remove _any_ handling of your search menu item on `onOptionsItemSelected`, override onKeyUp and make like this:

``` java
    private MenuItem mSearchMenuItem;

    @Override
    public boolean onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu menu) {
        getSupportMenuInflater().inflate(R.menu.myMenu, menu);
        mSearchMenuItem = menu.findItem(R.id.search);
        return true;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean onKeyUp(int keyCode, KeyEvent event) {
        switch (keyCode) {
            case KeyEvent.KEYCODE_SEARCH:
                return mSearchMenuItem != null ? mSearchMenuItem.expandActionView() : false;
            default:
                return super.onKeyUp(keyCode, event);
        }
    }
```

. Place your font in res/raw folder.
Use method `HoloFont.makeFont(**)` for creating a new instance of font object.
Also you can provide four styles of fonts (regular, bold, italic, bolditalic) like this:

``` java
            ROBOTO = makeFont(
                    ROBOTO_REGULAR = makeFont(R.raw.roboto_regular),
                    ROBOTO_BOLD = makeFont(R.raw.roboto_bold),
                    ROBOTO_ITALIC = makeFont(R.raw.roboto_italic),
                    ROBOTO_BOLD_ITALIC = makeFont(R.raw.roboto_bolditalic)
                    );
```

And finally call `FontLoader.setDefaultFont(HoloFont)` and this font will be everywhere in application.

No, it's /really/ android bug.
Any application have a two classloaders:
- System classloader. This classloader can load classes only from /system/framework folder. eg `android.*`.
- Application classloader. This can load classes from application apk. Activities, services and all others classes from apk. This classloader extend system classloader, and if use it everywhere - all ok.  
  FragmentManager doesn't set any classloader for savedinstance bundle, thats it's use system classloader, which simply don't know about apk anything.
. But we are use support library - potential, crashes in restore instance state (activity/fragment) /can/ be fixed, but...
Hardly.
. You can load class by name like this:

``` java
Class.forName("org.holoeverywhere.widget.ProgressBar$SavedState", true, context.getClassLoader())
```

without moving in org.holoeverywhere.widget package.

But modifying a origin layout has no effect. Text appearance for textview in layout present is two attrs:
textAppearanceSliderItem and textAppearanceSliderItemInverse. You can customize text appearance like this:

``` xml
<style name="CustomSliderTheme" parent="Holo.Internal.SliderTheme">
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItem">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem</item>
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItemInverse">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Inverse</item>
</style>
<style name="CustomSliderTheme.Light" parent="Holo.Internal.SliderTheme.Light">
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItem">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Light</item>
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItemInverse">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Inverse.Light</item>
</style>
```

. In Plugin 0.2.10 (will available in maven central for couple hours) like this:

```
holoeverywhere {
  signing.key 'myUniqueName'
  // or split for build variants:
  // signing {
  //   release.key 'releaseName'
  //   debug.key 'debugName'
  // }
}
```

Then put in ~/.gradle/gradle.properties (on Windows - C:\Users\<username>\.gradle\gradle.properties:

```
myUniqueNameStoreFile=/full/path/to/keystore
myUniqueNameStorePassword=Password
myUniqueNameKeyAlias=Alias
myUniqueNameKeyPassword=Password
```

Also you can provide this values directly in .gradle file:

```
holoeverywhere {
  signing {
    debug {
      storeFile = ...
      storePassword = ...
      keyAlias = ...
      keyPassword = ...
    }
    release {
      ...
    }
  }
}
```

. It's logical - you using appcompat theme, not holoeverywhere theme.
. Then Robolectric does set theme for activity. HoloEverywhere's runtime do it only if no other theme was specified, eg you have only basic activity declaration in manifest (without theme attribute).

I don't know exactly, how robolectric runs tests (i don't know even target platform for running, sorry), but it seems like robolectric's issue. 
. Did you try call supportRequestWindowFeature? And you should call it before super.onCreate, as I remember.
. If you can find a way for doing it with DrawerLayout - then you implement this feature. If you can provide patches for this for support library - you are good guy and I'll merge it with pleasure.

. HoloEverywhere doesn't provide a DatePicker anymore. But this means that native version of this widget will be using. But native DatePicker using a NumberPicker, which is still provided by library. Dilemma.

So you should use a native layout inflater (which will not override a widgets) for inflating a datepicker. Something like this:
main.xml:

``` xml
<LinearLayout
  xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:id="@+id/delete_diary_layout"
  android:layout_height="fill_parent" 
  android:minWidth="200dp"
  android:layout_width="fill_parent" android:orientation="vertical">
    <FrameLayout
        android:id="@+id/date_picker_panel"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content" />
</LinearLayout>
```

main_datepicker.xml:

``` xml
<DatePicker
    xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:id="@+id/date_picker"
    android:layout_width="wrap_content"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content" />
```

In your activity:

``` java
@Override
public void onCreate(Bundle savedState) {
  super.onCreate(savedState);
  setContentView(R.layout.main);
  android.view.LayoutInfalter nativeInflater = (android.view.LayoutInfalter) superGetSystemService(Context.LAYOUT_INFLATER_SERVICE);
  nativeInflater.inflate(R.layout.main_datepicker, (FrameLayout) findViewById(date_picker_panel), true);
}
```

. See demo. setForceThemeApply in Activity, ThemeManager.modifyDefaultTheme, ThemeManager.modify for all themes used in ThemeManager. And sure restartWith(Dark/Light/LightWithDarkActionBar)Theme. But it's restart, don't call it in onCreate.
. And Application.getConfig().setAlwaysUseParentTheme/setUseThemeManager
. Let's start by defining: you need to set a theme on Activity or on all application?
If first: is not satisfied setTheme?
If second: then yes, you should use ThemeManager. But does not enable the everything, in the hope that everything will work out.

`Application.getConfig().setUseThemeManager(true).setAlwaysUseParentTheme(true);` - as static block in your application class.

`ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.DARK)` Or LIGHT, LIGHT_WITH_DARK_ACTION_BAR. There also.
`ThemeManager.modify(ThemeManager.FULLSCREEN)` - if you want full screen theme.
`ThemeManager.modify(ThemeManager.NO_ACTION_BAR)` - and if you want theme without action bar.

On launcher activity you should set @Holo annotation with attr forceThemeApply = true, or call setForceThemeApply(true) before call super.onCreate.

For restart activity with new theme use ThemeManager.restartWith***Theme.
. With custom themes you should allow them to use. `ThemeManager.setOnlyBaseThemes(false)` before setting any themes.
. Application sample with using custom themes: [download](http://ubuntuone.com/3xNlkx4ozSHnVOSOkIlJUZ)
. About ListPreference: use getSupportSharedPreferences (or getDefaultPreferences), will be reverted to getSharedPreferences in next release.

package k.listviewtest;

import org.holoeverywhere.sherlock.SListActivity;

import android.os.Bundle;
import android.view.ContextMenu.ContextMenuInfo;
import android.view.View;
import android.widget.AdapterView.AdapterContextMenuInfo;
import android.widget.ArrayAdapter;

import com.actionbarsherlock.view.ContextMenu;

public class ListViewTestActivity extends SListActivity {
    private final String[] s = {
            "Item 1", "Item 2", "Item 3", "Item 4", "Item 5"
    };

    @Override
    protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
        registerForContextMenu(getListView());
        setListAdapter(new ArrayAdapter<String>(this, R.layout.simple_spinner_item,
                android.R.id.text1, s));
    }

    @Override
    public void onCreateContextMenu(ContextMenu menu, View view, ContextMenuInfo menuInfo) {
        getSupportActionBar().setSubtitle(
                "Position: " + ((AdapterContextMenuInfo) menuInfo).position);
    }
}

. Yes, I think a little clarification of the situation can not hurt.

`DialogFragment.show(FragmentManager, String)` and `DialogFragment.show(FragmentTransaction, String)` is deprecated because there were problems at 2.1-2.3 on restore instance state when tag == null. New methods simply generate tag name from class name and it's hashcode. But this methods also suggest that each DialogFragment's based class at any time will not be more than one instance. If this bothers you - you can use the old methods, it will not be deleted ever. But I recommend to use new methods, just in case ;)

</style>

PreferenceInit.map(R.style.CustomPreferenceTheme, R.style.CustomPreferenceTheme_Light);

. You are specify theme in manifest. When theme manager resolve activity theme and try to determine color scheme (dark/light/mixed), it's cannot resolve it. And it apply default PreferenceTheme - Dark.
Use ThemeManager: 

You can apply theme before onCreate:

``` java
setTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);
super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
```

Or define default application theme in Application class:

``` java
public class MyApplication extends org.holoeverywhere.app.Application {
  static {
    ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);
  }
}
```

``` java
    @Override
    protected void onPostCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {

    }

. onSearchRequested(), startSearch(), triggerSearch() and other don't supported by HoloEverywhere or ActionBarSherlock. You should change a behavior for correct handling of search feature.

Remove _any_ handling of your search menu item on `onOptionsItemSelected`, override onKeyUp and make like this:

``` java
    private MenuItem mSearchMenuItem;

    @Override
    public boolean onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu menu) {
        getSupportMenuInflater().inflate(R.menu.myMenu, menu);
        mSearchMenuItem = menu.findItem(R.id.search);
        return true;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean onKeyUp(int keyCode, KeyEvent event) {
        switch (keyCode) {
            case KeyEvent.KEYCODE_SEARCH:
                return mSearchMenuItem != null ? mSearchMenuItem.expandActionView() : false;
            default:
                return super.onKeyUp(keyCode, event);
        }
    }
```
. You should manually process suggestions with usage SearchView.setSuggestionsAdapter(CursorAdapter).

No, it's /really/ android bug.
Any application have a two classloaders:
- System classloader. This classloader can load classes only from /system/framework folder. eg `android.*`.
- Application classloader. This can load classes from application apk. Activities, services and all others classes from apk. This classloader extend system classloader, and if use it everywhere - all ok.  
  FragmentManager doesn't set any classloader for savedinstance bundle, thats it's use system classloader, which simply don't know about apk anything.
. But we are use support library - potential, crashes in restore instance state (activity/fragment) /can/ be fixed, but...
Hardly.
. You can load class by name like this:

``` java
Class.forName("org.holoeverywhere.widget.ProgressBar$SavedState", true, context.getClassLoader())
```

without moving in org.holoeverywhere.widget package.

But modifying a origin layout has no effect. Text appearance for textview in layout present is two attrs:
textAppearanceSliderItem and textAppearanceSliderItemInverse. You can customize text appearance like this:

``` xml
<style name="CustomSliderTheme" parent="Holo.Internal.SliderTheme">
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItem">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem</item>
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItemInverse">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Inverse</item>
</style>
<style name="CustomSliderTheme.Light" parent="Holo.Internal.SliderTheme.Light">
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItem">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Light</item>
  <item name="textAppearanceSliderItemInverse">@style/CustomTextAppearanceSliderItem.Inverse.Light</item>
</style>
```

```
apply plugin: 'holoeverywhere'
apply plugin: 'android'
```

by this:

```
apply plugin: 'holoeverywhere'
apply plugin: 'holoeverywhere-app'
```
. @8Duke8 as one more way: exclude appcompat library from your build lifecycle, HE already contains built-in appcompat variation.
. In Plugin 0.2.10 (will available in maven central for couple hours) like this:

```
holoeverywhere {
  signing.key 'myUniqueName'
  // or split for build variants:
  // signing {
  //   release.key 'releaseName'
  //   debug.key 'debugName'
  // }
}
```

Then put in ~/.gradle/gradle.properties (on Windows - C:\Users\<username>\.gradle\gradle.properties:

```
myUniqueNameStoreFile=/full/path/to/keystore
myUniqueNameStorePassword=Password
myUniqueNameKeyAlias=Alias
myUniqueNameKeyPassword=Password
```

Also you can provide this values directly in .gradle file:

```
holoeverywhere {
  signing {
    debug {
      storeFile = ...
      storePassword = ...
      keyAlias = ...
      keyPassword = ...
    }
    release {
      ...
    }
  }
}
```
. Good news guys: you can use normal repositories:
http://192.241.191.41/repo/
http://192.241.191.41/snapshot/
. Include _both_ repos for snapshot versions and _only first_ for release versions
. Well, you can support server by donations :D Distribution of files - hard work :)
. Artifact `android:android:4.3_r2` has been deployed to main repo.

_btw holoeverywhere plugin include both repos by default_
. Fixed with 0.2.16 release.

. HoloEverywhere doesn't provide a DatePicker anymore. But this means that native version of this widget will be using. But native DatePicker using a NumberPicker, which is still provided by library. Dilemma.

So you should use a native layout inflater (which will not override a widgets) for inflating a datepicker. Something like this:
main.xml:

``` xml
<LinearLayout
  xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
  android:id="@+id/delete_diary_layout"
  android:layout_height="fill_parent" 
  android:minWidth="200dp"
  android:layout_width="fill_parent" android:orientation="vertical">
    <FrameLayout
        android:id="@+id/date_picker_panel"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content" />
</LinearLayout>
```

main_datepicker.xml:

``` xml
<DatePicker
    xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:id="@+id/date_picker"
    android:layout_width="wrap_content"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content" />
```

In your activity:

``` java
@Override
public void onCreate(Bundle savedState) {
  super.onCreate(savedState);
  setContentView(R.layout.main);
  android.view.LayoutInfalter nativeInflater = (android.view.LayoutInfalter) superGetSystemService(Context.LAYOUT_INFLATER_SERVICE);
  nativeInflater.inflate(R.layout.main_datepicker, (FrameLayout) findViewById(date_picker_panel), true);
}
```

This is important to be able to call getNumberPicker from activity or fragment. Without being able to get from ui you cant set a formatter or displayValues array. Mine also has wrapSelectorWheel boolean in attrs, and has workaround for the focusability bug I closed earlier.
. closing this, will rebase and merge

ironjan:
Adding simply this line throws a NullPointerException in android.widget.AbsListView.setSelector on Android 2.3

The minimal style I could create was:

``` xml
  <style name="AutoCompleteTextViewHoloLight" parent="android:style/Widget.AutoCompleteTextView">
        <item name="android:background">@drawable/edit_text_holo_light</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">#000000</item>
        <item name="android:dropDownSelector">@drawable/list_selector_holo_light</item>
    </style>

    <style name="AutoCompleteTextViewHoloDark" parent="android:style/Widget.AutoCompleteTextView">
        <item name="android:background">@drawable/edit_text_holo_dark</item>
        <item name="android:textColor">#ffffff</item>
        <item name="android:dropDownSelector">@drawable/list_selector_holo_dark</item>
    </style>
```

Adding 

``` xml
        <item name="android:autoCompleteTextViewStyle">@style/AutoCompleteTextViewHoloLight</item>
```

or 

``` xml
        <item name="android:autoCompleteTextViewStyle">@style/AutoCompleteTextViewHoloLight</item>
```

to the coresponding themes solved crashing and styling. I did not have the time to test this completely.

Edit: DropDown-Items are white text on white background (light theme) on Android 2.3.
. Adding simply this line throws a NullPointerException in android.widget.AbsListView.setSelector on Android 2.3

``` xml
  <style name="AutoCompleteTextViewHoloLight" parent="android:style/Widget.AutoCompleteTextView">

Adding 

``` xml

```

or

```

to the coresponding themes solved crashing and styling. I did not have the time to test this completely.

PatteSMO:
Did some further testing when you said it could be ABS;

Removed ABS from activity -> Same problem.
Removed SlidingMenu from activity -> Same problem.

"@android:style/Theme.Light" was used as the un-dithered theme during testing.

Unfortunately, my only 2.2 testing device is an Optimus 2X, so I can't tell if it's caused by the ROM or something else. I will give it a try in the emulator and see if the problem occurs there too.

EDIT:
After emulator tests including screenshotting I can confirm that using the HoloEverywhere style Holo.Theme.Light instead of the android style Theme.Light makes the whole app dithered. This dithering is resulting in the performance loss.
. More testing showed that the window background was causing the problem. Commenting the following line solves this issue.

```
<item name="android:windowBackground">@drawable/background_holo_light</item>
```
. It has to do with the windowBackground property, so I guess that applies for every theme. 
. Will try that when I get home (in ~ 40 min) and report the results, thank you. 
. Unfortunately, it did not help. Same problem with or without the "fake" alpha.
. However, that creates problem with devices that are capable of rendering ARGB_8888 with high performance. I think I'll just stick to just skipping the background, it's the easiest solution for me ;)
. I can confirm that the vertical divider isn't showing up on Android 2.x.
. Only have a 4.x device with me, but I pointed out the vertical divider with an arrow. This divider is invisible (or probably just some alpha variant of white) on 2.x devices. 

Screenshot: https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B4zruXZsxrs4eDRNd2k4RnJ2YkU/edit
. Edit: Can't make Drive file public from mobile, please use this dropbox link instead http://db.tt/qvd6sUsX

. Strange, are you using Holo.Theme.White or the ABS equivalent? 
. Judging by the content of the online styles.xml file there shouldn't be a problem with the divider color. I will do some testing on this again later today. 
. I found that changing this tag to "com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.widget.LinearLayout" solved the problem.
https://github.com/ChristopheVersieux/HoloEverywhere/blob/master/library/res/layout/alert_dialog_holo.xml#L94

Note that the end tag must be replaced as well.
. I expected that behaviour too, but the LG Optimus 2X beside me proofs it inflated the default android.widget.LinearLayout instead.
. @ChrisDavis8 Does that mean I have to change from using ActionbarSherlockActivity directly to using the one in com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.sherlock?
. Turns out I had to extend SActivity, but I must agree that it's far from obvious. For my adapters I had to wrap the views around FontLoader.apply(), but that was more obvious once you got into the "replace every possible class" thinking :)

nicomott:
Yes, I should have said it, I tried every methods on DialogFragment, nothing works.
. Ok so I think that the bug in is DialogFragment class, line 181. We try to get the inherited field "mContainerId" like this: 

```
Field field = getClass().getField("mContainerId");
```

It will always throw a NoSuchFieldException, because it's not declared in this class, but in the superclass android.support.v4.app.Fragment.
. I don't think there is a better way, but I may be wrong. 
Anyway, I fixed that with this code, maybe someone will have something cleaner later : 

```
Class<?> supportFragmentClass = getClass().getSuperclass().getSuperclass().getSuperclass().getSuperclass();
Field field = supportFragmentClass.getDeclaredField("mContainerId");
```

tmurakami:
I had this same issue.
By using the "fragment" tag in a layout.xml, ClassCastException occurs.

Reason:
HoloEverywhere has a custom LayoutInflater.
However, because it overrides Activity#getLayoutInflater, Factory is not set.
(Normally, Factory is set at FragmentActivity#onCreate.)

Workaround:
Add the following code to your activity.

```
@Override
public com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.LayoutInflater getLayoutInflater() {
  return (com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.LayoutInflater)getWindow().getLayoutInflater();
}
```
. getSystemService() has been overridden by com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.app.Activity.
Therefore, I think getWindow().getLayoutInflater() returns HoloEverywhere's LayoutInflater.

The cause of this issue is that Factory is not set to LayoutInflater returned by getSystemServices().
Therefore, I used the above code.
With that code, Factory is set at FragmentActivity#onCreate.

I think also this issue is solved using the following code.

```
@Override
public Object getSystemService(String name) {
  Object service = super.getSystemService(name);
  if (service instanceof com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.LayoutInflater) {
    com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.LayoutInflater li = (com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.LayoutInflater)service;
    if (li.getFactory() == null) {
      li.setFactory(this);
    }
  }
  return service;
}
```
. With HoloEverywhere 1.3, my project works fine!
Thanks for your good work!
. It seems to be an Android bug.
see: http://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=37484
. I also faced a similar problem using multi choice mode.
To avoid this problem, I added the **modalBackgroundWrapper** to my theme.

res/values/styles.xml

``` xml
<style name="MyTheme" parent="Holo.Theme.Light.DarkActionBar">
  <item name="modalBackgroundWrapper">@drawable/my_activatable_background</item>
</style>
```

res/drawable/my_activatable_background.xml

``` xml
<selector xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">
  <item android:drawable="@drawable/my_pressed_background" android:state_pressed="true"/>
  <item android:drawable="@drawable/my_focused_background" android:state_focused="true"/>
  <item android:drawable="@drawable/my_focused_background" android:state_selected="true"/>
  <item android:drawable="@drawable/my_activated_background" android:state_activated="true"/>
  <item android:drawable="@drawable/my_activated_background" android:state_checked="true"/>
  <item android:drawable="@color/transparent"/>
</selector>
```
. @RemieM The **modalBackgroundWrapper** is used in **org.holoeverywhere.widget.ModalBackgroundWrapper** that is a wrapper for list item.
https://github.com/ChristopheVersieux/HoloEverywhere/blob/master/library/src/org/holoeverywhere/widget/ModalBackgroundWrapper.java#L29
https://github.com/ChristopheVersieux/HoloEverywhere/blob/master/library/src/org/holoeverywhere/widget/ListView.java#L531

. IMHO, I don't beleive it should be included in HoloEverywhere. It's out of scope. May be @JackeWharton could give us an opinion about it.

BTW, I think it should be wrapped from ActionBarSherlock rather than from HoloEverywhere, as it is a closer layer to the wrapper of android support library v4.
. HoloEverywhere by itself doesn't, but you can use https://github.com/JakeWharton/ActionBarSherlock-Plugin-Maps that  gives support to MapActivity.

The thing is that you can't use a MapView inside a Fragment because when it detaches the fragment's layout (e.g. changing among tabs) the MapView is leaked (remains attached to it's parent view). So when you try to attach the fragment again you get a runtimeexception related to only being able to have one MapView per MapActivity.

As a workaround, I kept the instance of the MapView inside the instance of the Fragment. When the onCreate() is called I saved the instance, and when the onCreateView() is called I made an addView() to the rootView. Then, in onDestroyView() y did removeView() of the MapView instance from it's parent.
. Good news. New maps api was released 4 days ago as part of Google Play Services v2. Therefore, extending from MapActivity is no longer needed to hold a MapView. You just have to extend from Activity as usual, and use the new MapFragment.

Given this, the issue may be closed if MapFragment is fully supported.

More info:
- http://android-developers.blogspot.com.br/2012/12/new-google-maps-android-api-now-part-of.html.
- https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android/start#getting_the_google_maps_android_api_v2

. What i figured via black box testing, AS THERE IS NO DOCUMENTATION, which is a real issue is:
You cannot change a theme on an application level. You have to do it individually in for each activity.
Another complicatin is that you cannot use SharedPreferences as there is no way to init them to some default value.
So you have to find a way to persist and init your settings.
And in some cases you must be carefull which context are you using. Application context does not necesarilly carry all the information an activity context does.
. Can it be that you are trying to mix interface android.content.ContextWrapper with interface com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.app.Base.
They both have the abstract method getSharedPreferences(java.lang.String,int), yet those two abstract methods return different ypes. Former one returns android.content.SharedPreferences while the latter one one returns com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.preference.SharedPreferences.

I think this might be tracked down to using wrong import.

. Regarding this issue I would politely like to ask something.
In android  documentation it is stated that the preferred method of using DatePickerDialog (in regular android) is to extend DialogFragment and wrap DatePickerDialog inside it. (source: http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/controls/pickers.html#TimePickerFragment)

However in HoloEverywhere, as stated in this topic, you have extended DatiPickerDialog from DialogFragment. Is there a reason behind it?
The usage as far as I could get it is to extend DatePickerDialog as this one is in itself already extended from fragment. How to initialize it I haven't figured yet. Wouldn't it be then more intuitive to name DatePickerDialog to something like DatePickerDialogFragment?

For information I have included packages and hierarchies of DatePickerDialog class in both Android and HoloEverywhere.

Android

```
Package
android.app.DatePickerDialog.OnDateSetListener

Hierarchy
android.app.Dialog
    android.app.AlertDialog
        android.app.DatePickerDialog
```

HoloEverywhere

```
Package
org.holoeverywhere.widget.datetimepicker.date.DatePickerDialog

Hierarchy
android.support.v4.app._HoloFragment
    org.holoeverywhere.app.Fragment
        org.holoeverywhere.app.DialogFragment
            org.holoeverywhere.widget.datetimepicker.date.DatePickerDialog
```

What bothers is that there is no parallel between android and holoeverywhere classes. This is not useful for making use of regular android patterns and documentation. Such parallelism makes it a lot easier to convert an application to holoeverywhere and to convert it back to regular android in the future, when there are few enough older devices.
But I guess holoeverywhere will support android 7.x look an 4.y devices by then.

. What i figured via black box testing, AS THERE IS NO DOCUMENTATION, which is a real issue is:
You cannot change a theme on an application level. You have to do it individually in for each activity.
Another complicatin is that you cannot use SharedPreferences as there is no way to init them to some default value.
So you have to find a way to persist and init your settings.
And in some cases you must be carefull which context are you using. Application context does not necesarilly carry all the information an activity context does.
. Can it be that you are trying to mix interface android.content.ContextWrapper with interface com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.app.Base.
They both have the abstract method getSharedPreferences(java.lang.String,int), yet those two abstract methods return different ypes. Former one returns android.content.SharedPreferences while the latter one one returns com.WazaBe.HoloEverywhere.preference.SharedPreferences.

I think this might be tracked down to using wrong import.

. Regarding this issue I would politely like to ask something.
In android  documentation it is stated that the preferred method of using DatePickerDialog (in regular android) is to extend DialogFragment and wrap DatePickerDialog inside it. (source: http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/controls/pickers.html#TimePickerFragment)

However in HoloEverywhere, as stated in this topic, you have extended DatiPickerDialog from DialogFragment. Is there a reason behind it?
The usage as far as I could get it is to extend DatePickerDialog as this one is in itself already extended from fragment. How to initialize it I haven't figured yet. Wouldn't it be then more intuitive to name DatePickerDialog to something like DatePickerDialogFragment?

For information I have included packages and hierarchies of DatePickerDialog class in both Android and HoloEverywhere.

Android

```
Package
android.app.DatePickerDialog.OnDateSetListener

Hierarchy
android.app.Dialog
    android.app.AlertDialog
        android.app.DatePickerDialog
```

HoloEverywhere

```
Package
org.holoeverywhere.widget.datetimepicker.date.DatePickerDialog

Hierarchy
android.support.v4.app._HoloFragment
    org.holoeverywhere.app.Fragment
        org.holoeverywhere.app.DialogFragment
            org.holoeverywhere.widget.datetimepicker.date.DatePickerDialog
```

What bothers is that there is no parallel between android and holoeverywhere classes. This is not useful for making use of regular android patterns and documentation. Such parallelism makes it a lot easier to convert an application to holoeverywhere and to convert it back to regular android in the future, when there are few enough older devices.
But I guess holoeverywhere will support android 7.x look an 4.y devices by then.

My custom theme was:

```
<style name="ThemeCustom" parent="Holo.Theme.Light.DarkActionBar.Fullscreen">
…
    <item name="android:checkboxStyle">@style/Holo.CompoundButton.CheckBox.Custom</item>
    <item name="android:checkBoxPreferenceStyle">@style/Holo.CompoundButton.CheckBox.Custom</item>
…
</style>
```

These Holo.CompoundButton.CheckBox.Custom have different drawables. Everything else is the same. When I use this theme on my preference activity nothing is changed. The normal holo checkbox is used, not my custom drawables.

Upon closer look I added following line into my theme:

```
<item name="preferenceTheme">@style/ThemeCustom</item> <!-- application theme -->
```

This had the effect that the backround selectin color changed and that the CheckBoxed dissapearad completely.
A liitle more insight how is the preference screen styled would be beneficial.

imgen:
Hi, after awful lot of googling, I found the solution, the culprit is the java compiler level, by default it is 1.5. After moving to java 1.6, it worked flawlessly. Sorry for the complaining, but the readme should be more specific about this, otherwise, 1888 errors will show up, it's a bit overwhelming. Anyway, this issue is resolved. I'm glad it did. 
. Hi, after awful lot of googling, I found the solution, the culprit is the java compiler level, by default it is 1.5. After moving to java 1.6, it worked flawlessly. Sorry for the complaining, but the readme should be more specific about this, otherwise, 1888 errors will show up, it's a bit overwhelming. Anyway, this issue is resolved. I'm glad it did. 
.
ChrLipp:
I think the reason is the same as was noted in Issue 134 (see https://github.com/ChristopheVersieux/HoloEverywhere/issues/134 ):

Quote: _I know that ActionBarSherlock (4.2.0) has been updated and that HoloEverywhere is using classes no longer existing in the current Google Support library r10 (i.e.: Watson)_

Issue 134 was closed without fixing the issue. However, current HoloEverywhere doesn't compile with current Google Support library r10 (last working ist r7).

edubsi:
Your Code looks fine to me. What I am doing is:

```
preferences = PreferenceManager.getDefaultSharedPreferences(this);
int themeId = preferences.getInt(SHARED_PREFERENCES_THEME, R.style.Holo_Theme);
setTheme(themeId);
super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
```

It is important that you set your Theme before you set your Content View && call the onCreate (That's what I figured out right now)
You mean the ActionBar with TitleBar?
Here is a Question on StackOverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8456835/how-to-disable-action-bar-permanently
Basically it is:
- getActionBar.hide()  OR getSupportActionBar.hide()
- set the Theme to "Theme.Holo.Light.NoActionBar" e.g.

Good Luck hope it was helpful.

. Ok, seems that cause is in mStatesMap of IAddon class. It is WeakHashMap. Keys are weakreferences but not values. To fix memory leak we can use such approach

``` java
@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
    public <T, V extends IAddonBase<T>> V obtain(T object) {
        try {
            WeakReference<V> addonRef = (WeakReference<V>) mStatesMap
                    .get(object);
            V addon = addonRef == null ? null : addonRef.get();
            if (addon != null) {
                return addon;
            }
            Class<?> clazz = object.getClass();
            while (!mTypesMap.containsKey(clazz)) {
                if (clazz == Object.class) {
                    // Nothing was found
                    return null;
                }
                clazz = clazz.getSuperclass();
            }
            addon = ((Class<V>) mTypesMap.get(clazz)).newInstance();
            addon.attach(object);
            mStatesMap.put(object, new WeakReference<V>(addon));
            return addon;
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException(e);
        }
    }
```

. Ok, seems that cause is in mStatesMap of IAddon class. It is WeakHashMap. Keys are weakreferences but not values. To fix memory leak we can use such approach

``` java
@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
    public <T, V extends IAddonBase<T>> V obtain(T object) {
        try {
            WeakReference<V> addonRef = (WeakReference<V>) mStatesMap
                    .get(object);
            V addon = addonRef == null ? null : addonRef.get();
            if (addon != null) {
                return addon;
            }
            Class<?> clazz = object.getClass();
            while (!mTypesMap.containsKey(clazz)) {
                if (clazz == Object.class) {
                    // Nothing was found
                    return null;
                }
                clazz = clazz.getSuperclass();
            }
            addon = ((Class<V>) mTypesMap.get(clazz)).newInstance();
            addon.attach(object);
            mStatesMap.put(object, new WeakReference<V>(addon));
            return addon;
        } catch (Exception e) {

soarcn:
i have migrated to 1.4, most of issues related to dialog. which at least working correct in 1.3

precondition: turn off "always use parent theme", unless the theme setting will be ignore.
- use "Theme.Dialog" for preferenceActitivity, the screen size is not correct. try to reproduce this, please use following code in demo app.
  setTitle("short"); //important
  addPreferencesFromResource(R.xml.preferences);
- background and frame will also be shown in dialogfragment even we set DialogFragment.STYLE_NO_FRAME.
- preference will lost after the upgrade
- I would suggest HE still use XML preference imp as default one, since json imp not support some feature.
- suggest turn off background music as default in demo app

And thanks for you great work to bring this lib to us!
. @Prototik  please test it in android 2.3, I can reproduce with my defy.
and Dialog activity defects can be fixed by add those items to Theme:
        <item name="windowMinWidthMajor">@dimen/dialog_min_width_major</item>
        <item name="windowMinWidthMinor">@dimen/dialog_min_width_minor</item>

till now haven't found the fix for FragmentDialog, I will upload screenshot later.
. ![](http://www.cocosw.com/1.png)
Dialog fragmentactivity in android 2.3

![](http://www.cocosw.com/2.png)
dialogfragment NO_FRAME

I use the test code from ABS fragment FragmentDialogSupport.java
. @Prototik 
the Activity dialog theme  seems working correct now. 

but the (fragment)dialog still not correct. as you can see in the second screenshot, with NO_FRAME theme, there should have no frame(backgroud picture) around the dialog.

I checked the code, and found the root cause in DialogFragment.java  168

```
public Dialog onCreateDialog(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
return new AlertDialog(getActivity(), getTheme());
}
```

the correct way is 

```
public Dialog onCreateDialog(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
return new Dialog(getActivity(), getTheme());
}
```

I compared the HE 1.3, seems this is a change in 1.4

I make a workaround in my app layer to override the onCreateDialog, in that way, working perfect.

I would suggest HE could use some testcase UI besides demo application, for example use apidemo application(View section), that would be a easy way to cover most of real case. even looks not that fancy.
. thanks!

jomp16:
What version of the Android API are you using?

In outdated APIs, the HoloEverywhere and Actionbar Sherlock doesn't work, need a newest API, like API 17 (I'm using 17 right now)

Try to change the project API to 17, and add android:minSdkVersion="10" (or other) on AndroidManifest to add support to older API ;)

(Sorry for my english :P)
. I use this way: create a new project, and FILE -> IMPORT MODULE, select the "library" folder of Holoeverywhere, and I repeat this but now with Sherlock, and open project settings, add android-v4-support.jar to the 3 projects, add Sherlock to Holoeverywhere, and add the Sherlock and Holoeverywhere to the main project, now working :)

. Here is workaround:
Clone HoloEverywhere into projectRoot/repo, checkout branch to repo. Add this into your project's build.gradle:

```
allprojects {
    repositories {
        maven { url "${rootProject.projectDir}/repo" }
        mavenCentral()
        mavenLocal()
    }
}
```

mattprecious:
For what it's worth, the value is changed in `PreferenceGroup.addPreference()` when it executes

```
preference.onAttachedToHierarchy(getPreferenceManager());
```

where it eventually calls through to `Preference.dispatchSetInitialValue()`.

Everything I traced through from there is identical to AOSP and seems to be coded to do the right thing. The only thing I can think of that might be different is that maybe in AOSP, `mDefaultValue` is null, but in HE it's `Boolean.FALSE`. I don't really have the ability to test that theory.

Anyway, looking back on this two months later, using `setDefaultValue(true)` is probably the correct way for me to handle this, so this fix is definitely super low priority. However, since the result does differ from AOSP, it may be something to consider digging into deeper eventually.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"

    android:orientation="horizontal"
    android:weightSum="5" >

    <View
        android:id="@+id/red_separator"
        android:layout_width="4dp"
        android:layout_height="match_parent"
        android:background="@color/red" />

    <LinearLayout
        android:id="@+id/my_layout_parameter_container"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="match_parent"
        android:layout_weight="4"
        android:orientation="vertical" >

    </LinearLayout>

    <View
        android:id="@+id/my_layout_separator"
        android:layout_width="1dp"
        android:layout_height="match_parent"
        android:background="@color/text_gray" />

    <LinearLayout
        android:id="@+id/my_layout_actions_container"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="match_parent"
        android:layout_weight="1"
        android:gravity="center_horizontal"
        android:orientation="vertical"
        android:weightSum="2" >

            android:id="@+id/my_layout_checkbox"
            android:layout_width="wrap_content"
            android:layout_height="0dp"

        <ImageView

            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="0dp"
            android:layout_weight="1"
            android:background="@drawable/selector"
            android:contentDescription="change button"
            android:scaleType="centerInside"
            android:src="@drawable/ic_action_edit_default" />
    </LinearLayout>

</LinearLayout>

But that begs a couple of questions:

. But that means I can have a build with this as a dependency:

<dependency>
            <groupId>com.android.support</groupId>
            <artifactId>support-v4</artifactId>
            <version>19.1.0</version>
</dependency>
```

and it will use 2 totally different artifacts depending on whose machine it is built on.

HE has no right to be publishing artifacts in the `com.android.support` group. That is the prerogative of the owner of the android project.

It would be like me publishing `org.holoeverywhere:library:2.1.0` with my own versions of the HE classes.

uKL:
Hi, 

I'm emailing you an example where this bug occurs. It occurs for example when you implement a drawer(sliding menu). I'm implementing my own drawer, however this example uses SlidingMenu.

It looks like it freeze drawing process, but motion events are processed properly.

Moreover, the issue appears only on pre-Honeycomb devices (emulator as well).
. I'm sorry but for now I'm unable to go public with my implementation. 

However what I'm doing is injecting a view between **DecorView** and it's child. Probably **SlidingMenu** does the same and it causes problems on pre-HC devices. Without HoloEverywhere all looks fine. Particularly without using **Nineoldandroid proxyAnimator** (look at yout FrameLayout). In the mentioned commit you have started remaping **FrameLayouts**
. BTW. To reproduce, just rotate the screen and try touching the button.
. Thanks, it should work now. I will check and update here. When can we expect next stable release containing this fix?

. If you're using version 2.1 of the library, use this in your build.gradle file to the dependencies
    compile 'com.android.support:support-v4:18.0.4@jar'
    compile 'org.holoeverywhere:library:2.1.0@aar'

And this to the repositories section:
    maven { url "https://github.com/Prototik/HoloEverywhere/raw/repo" }
. Thanks to everyone involved in this project. Thanks to @ChristopheVersieux for starting it, to @Prototik for maintaining it and for everyone that submitted pull requests with bug fixes.
Using HoloEverywhere in the AndroidPIT app resulted, IMHO, in a much better experience for the user, even with all the headaches that it sometimes gave me.
Android 2.2 is dead, 2.3 is also going to the grave soon and hopefully developers won't need to use this library anymore. I'm glad I was able to convince the product team of "my" app to use this library and I'm hoping that I'll contribute to your development projects someday, just like you contributed to mine. Thanks again @ChristopheVersieux and @Prototik for all the effort. Maybe I'll meet you someday in person and buy you a drink. Merci beaucoup and Большое спасибо.

OS-Chris:
It is due to the support library in ActionBarSherlock (which all the other projects link to) which is missing some things from support-library/android-support-v4-r12.jar.

Maybe have a mention in the "How to use" section to swap the ActionBarSherlock lib to the r12 version.
Also maybe a quick mention on how to use the addons (i.e. SlidingMenu & Preferences).

Anyway, thanks for sharing your work. Awesome library !!
. Didn't notice your comment before posting my issue. Sorry about that.

From the API docs: "This can only be used with fragments not in the back stack. If set, the fragment lifecycle will be slightly different when an activity is recreated". I might be mistaken but unless you have a basic app, this may not be the way to go.

IMO, find a tutorial on "onSaveInstanceState" and save your state manually for complete control. My app was saving & reloading perfectly before Fix #508 was uploaded (no big deal, I just reverted that commit).
. You can't include android libraries as JAR files, they must be imported as an Eclipse project and linked to your project through the Android tab on the properties of your project.

I had drama's setting it up initially as well. Turns out another library I used was using a different support library so my project ended up with 2 versions and spazzed out. What I did was replace all support-xxxxx.jar libraries with the r13 one, refreshed and rebuilt all projects and no more errors.
. Make sure your class extends org.holoeverywhere.app._Fragment or org.holoeverywhere.app._Activity (not Sherlock*)
. Use org.holoeverywhere.app.Activity instead of SherlockFragmentActivity and use org.holoeverywhere.app.Fragment instead of SherlockFragment.

HoloEverywhere internally uses ActionBarSherlock so your app should basically remove all ActionBarSherlock imports (there are only a few that don't have HoloEverywhere equivalents).

If you need, study the demo source code to see how it all fits together (i.e. how to load fragments).

. Make sure your class extends org.holoeverywhere.app._Fragment or org.holoeverywhere.app._Activity (not Sherlock*)
. Use org.holoeverywhere.app.Activity instead of SherlockFragmentActivity and use org.holoeverywhere.app.Fragment instead of SherlockFragment.

HoloEverywhere internally uses ActionBarSherlock so your app should basically remove all ActionBarSherlock imports (there are only a few that don't have HoloEverywhere equivalents).

Sure, it's nothing special. Just a Done / Discard layout for the ActionBar:

``` xml
<org.holoeverywhere.widget.LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:orientation="horizontal"
    android:divider="?android:attr/dividerVertical"
    android:showDividers="middle"
    android:dividerPadding="12dp">

    <include layout="@layout/actionbar_discard_button" />

    <include layout="@layout/actionbar_done_button" />
</org.holoeverywhere.widget.LinearLayout>
```

The buttons are like this: 

``` xml
<org.holoeverywhere.widget.FrameLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    style="?android:actionButtonStyle"
    android:id="@+id/actionbar_discard"
    android:background="@drawable/selectable_background_holo_green"
    android:layout_width="0dp"
    android:layout_height="match_parent"
    android:layout_weight="1">

    <org.holoeverywhere.widget.TextView
        style="?android:actionBarTabTextStyle"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:layout_gravity="center"
        android:paddingRight="20dp"
        android:drawableLeft="@drawable/action_discard"
        android:drawablePadding="8dp"
        android:gravity="center_vertical"
        android:text="@string/discard" />

</org.holoeverywhere.widget.FrameLayout>
```

dmmh:
Thanks for your reply. I looked at your suggestion and it seems I don't understand what you mean. I have the theme applied on application context.

using this in every variation I tried:
<application
        android:name=".subclasses.ApplicationSubclass"
        android:allowBackup="true"
        android:allowClearUserData="true"
        android:hasCode="true"
        android:icon="@drawable/ic_launcher"
        android:label="@string/app_name"
        android:theme="@style/Holo.Theme" >

My application subclass extends org.holoeverywhere.app.Application. Also tried android.app.Application. Doesn't make any difference.

I actually don't need application context on the Preference's itself, but I do need to pass the application context because I need it for other stuff, like registering receivers, and sending notifications with NotificationManager. Since there isn't an alternative constructor, this isn't possible. And a non-default constructor probably wouldn't be recommended anyway. This isn't far fetched, people would be activating and de-activating receivers via CheckBoxPreference quite often I guess. 

I will explain further. I am using a FragmentStatePagerAdapter. It's constructor creates the fragments, which are PreferenceFragments. Everything referencing HoloEverywhere ofcourse. The fragments create the PreferenceScreen's in the same way as shown above. I merely simplified the example, because it also doesn't work by code in a simple PreferenceActivity, which is unexpected behaviour. 

Also, it deviates from the default Preference framework. This is strange, because it really shouldn't make any difference what context is being used. In most cases, application context is more usefull anyway. I do still feel this is an issue that could be resolved. It's really weird having to pass in 2 contexts, when normally one is sufficient. Also, there is no way to wrap context (or set) on any of HoloEverywhere's Preference classes. Am I missing something?

If you mean I should modify the library itself, I don't think this is recommended. Also, since I am using this library in my own library project, I wouldn't get the right context, since the ApplicationSubclass won't work in a library. You must mean something else. Also, I don't see the point in wrapping anything, because it would still crash, as it's still the same application context.

vitakot:
Unfortunately not. I do not use screen rotation, just starting the app, pressing back and then call GC explicitly in the Eclipse DDMS view. After each such cycle memory allocation grows by several KB and never goes back, the exact amount depends on the actual device, screen size/density and the layout complexity.

I am testing it on Nexus 7 (Android 4.2.2, 1280 x 800 px). I have a simple login activity with three buttons on a black background, after each start/finish cycle the memory heap grows by 70 kB and the number of allocated object increases by approx. one thousand.

Just to note, previous version (from about two month ago) did not leak so much. Yesterday I updated to the latest revision and found out that the memory leakage has significantly increased.
. I have created a sample project using Google maps v2 API, it is in public SVN repository on Assembla:

https://www.assembla.com/code/gmaps_v2_mem_leak/subversion/nodes

There are a really huge memory leaks in conjunction with your library. After the first application start there is about 4 MB and 70 000 objects allocated in the VM heap, after five cycles of back/start it raises to 7 MB and 100 000 objects. Such a leak inevitably leads to OOM exception and app kill in a short time.

If I use native android.support.v4.app.FragmentActivity instead of your org.holoeverywhere.app.Activity, there are no memory leaks. More precisely, there are also leaks, but only these which introduces maps API as such – it is known and confirmed bug: http://code.google.com/p/gmaps-api-issues/issues/detail?id=4766

It looks I have no option than not to use holoeverywhere library and to create necessary styles on my own.

Testing device: LG-P970, Android 2.3.4

Dahlgren:
Since existing maven repos contain apklibs instead of the new aar format which Gradle uses you'll have to compile and package ActionBarSherlock with gradle to a local repo. ActionBarSherlock already got a Gradle build file in the dev-branch. Another issue is that the Android support library in the central maven repository is only r7. Solve this by adding r13 from HoloEverywhere to your local maven repo. Doing this allowed me to successfully build HoloEverywhere libraries and addons which I then used to run both the demo app and some of my own projects using Gradle. I'll create a fork later today with needed build scripts setup if anyone else is interested.
. Fork is up at https://github.com/Dahlgren/HoloEverywhere/tree/gradle

Since ABS and Android support library is not available from public mirrors I've added a local maven repo with them inside the project folder.

Let me know if you need any more help!
. Since existing maven repos contain apklibs instead of the new aar format which Gradle uses you'll have to compile and package ActionBarSherlock with gradle to a local repo. ActionBarSherlock already got a Gradle build file in the dev-branch. Another issue is that the Android support library in the central maven repository is only r7. Solve this by adding r13 from HoloEverywhere to your local maven repo. Doing this allowed me to successfully build HoloEverywhere libraries and addons which I then used to run both the demo app and some of my own projects using Gradle. I'll create a fork later today with needed build scripts setup if anyone else is interested.
. Fork is up at https://github.com/Dahlgren/HoloEverywhere/tree/gradle

Since ABS and Android support library is not available from public mirrors I've added a local maven repo with them inside the project folder.

Let me know if you need any more help!

appixia:
There are 2 main problems:
1. The basic app with a ViewPager takes a minimum of 5 nested views (mostly due to ABS and support lib)
2. Every fragment takes a min of 3 views (mostly due to ABS and support lib), since I use nested fragments I get an extra of 6 nested views

The stack size of UI thread in Android 2.x is 12KB and in Android 4.x is 16KB. These 4KB make all the difference - since the above layout crashes on 2.x with StackOverflow.

My current solution was to stop using fragments altogether (this saved me 5 views total). So right now instead of a fragment I'm just adding ViewGroups manually. Kinda sucks that I can't use fragments, but they are too wasteful on views until we fix this some how.
. @Prototik I think we should consider helping with this issue although obviously it isn't a holoeverywhere problem. The point of holoeverywhere is to support older (2.x) devices. If supporting them fails due to stack overflows, and we can somehow help it will really contribute to the value holoeverywhere gives programmers.
. I had some crazy idea to create my own UI thread with a larger stack size. Do you think it's possible? It will be difficult since there is no documented way to do it, but it will solve the problem at the core
. Thanks for keeping the issue open!
I'll experiment with creating a larger UI stack manually - already posted a stackoverflow question about it to get ideas: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16913317/create-the-ui-thread-manually-in-android-in-order-to-increase-its-small-stack-si

I've also researched and found in dalvik/vm/Thread.h source that the default stack size was increased from 12KB to 16KB in Android 4.x, so they know there's a problem there. On Android 1.5 it was 8KB, simply ridiculous
. @tkiela Removing the ContextMenuDecorView wasn't enough for me because I had a lot of nested views. I ended up not using fragments anymore at all. I'm still using HoloEverywhere but I replaced all fragments with manual ViewGroups. This means I'm adding, animating and removing ViewGroups manually. It behaves just like fragments, but I have full control on exactly how many views I have

antonyt:
I have seen this problem on the Sony Xperia Acro (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Xperia_acro) when running Android 2.3.x. I have not seen this problem on any 4.x Sony device.

The problem is caused by the HoloEverywhere LinearLayout. I am not sure exactly where, but in any case, disabling it causes the layout to render with proper dimensions. To disable the LinearLayout only, you can call LayoutInflater.register(...) with your own LinearLayout class (e.g. the default one), which will take priority. You also need to update all of the existing references to the HoloEverywhere LinearLayout to point to your new LinearLayout class (or the default parent class). I only do this for 2.x Sony devices.

Finding the root cause is obviously the best fix but I have not been able to spend enough time with the device either.

FYI: There is a (paid, in Japanese only) testing service called Remote Testkit (appkitbox.com/testkit) which has devices which exhibit this problem.

. You are right, the fault didn't lie with holoeverywhere :  
I thought that the big 1MB bitmap that I discovered in MAT was a memory leak, but it was actually an android system bitmap (shared by the zygotte process) to provide a nice background for the listviews. Those stackoverflow thread made this clear : 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18594576/android-edgeeffect-appears-to-allocate-a-1-meg-bitmap
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18515647/strange-bitmap-using-1-mb-of-heap 
. Thanks for this great piece of work. It really helped me and a lot of other people out there.

"Couldn't determine a final version"
. Personnatly, after 1 month I couldn't wait anymore and switched to the official AppCompat lib. 
It took me 2~3 days and 2000 compilation errors to fix but now it works just fine. 
Removing all holoeverywhere imports fixed like 1000+ compilations error then you have to fix a few issues (not that much)  : 
FragmentActivity or ActionBarctivity instead of Activity
Style must inherit from Material theme instead of Holo...
id for preferences -> key string (use the makeKeyFromId method from holoeverywhere and use your id name as a key string)
getSupportActionBar
getSupportFragmentManager
prefix by app: instead of android: for menuItem
...
hope it helps...

I take this opportunity to again give my thanks for Holoeverywhere : 
For a long time, Google released lots of android version and Holoeverywhere was the only library that allowed us to have consistent themes/behavior on all those versions. It was doing the job that appCompat is doing now... Damn google for taking so long to release a support library as good as Holoeverywhere (and praise to Prototik, ChristopheVersieux & cie)

. You are right, the fault didn't lie with holoeverywhere :  
I thought that the big 1MB bitmap that I discovered in MAT was a memory leak, but it was actually an android system bitmap (shared by the zygotte process) to provide a nice background for the listviews. Those stackoverflow thread made this clear : 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18594576/android-edgeeffect-appears-to-allocate-a-1-meg-bitmap
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18515647/strange-bitmap-using-1-mb-of-heap 
. Thanks for this great piece of work. It really helped me and a lot of other people out there.

. Personnatly, after 1 month I couldn't wait anymore and switched to the official AppCompat lib. 
It took me 2~3 days and 2000 compilation errors to fix but now it works just fine. 
Removing all holoeverywhere imports fixed like 1000+ compilations error then you have to fix a few issues (not that much)  : 
FragmentActivity or ActionBarctivity instead of Activity
Style must inherit from Material theme instead of Holo...
id for preferences -> key string (use the makeKeyFromId method from holoeverywhere and use your id name as a key string)
getSupportActionBar
getSupportFragmentManager
prefix by app: instead of android: for menuItem
...
hope it helps...

I take this opportunity to again give my thanks for Holoeverywhere : 
For a long time, Google released lots of android version and Holoeverywhere was the only library that allowed us to have consistent themes/behavior on all those versions. It was doing the job that appCompat is doing now... Damn google for taking so long to release a support library as good as Holoeverywhere (and praise to Prototik, ChristopheVersieux & cie)

. Well, I try add to proguard config:

But it did no help me.
. This problem is not holoeverywhere. You need to configure proguard.
For example, add the following:

-keep class android.*\* { _; }
-keep class android.support.v4._\* { _; }
-keep public class \* extends android.support.v4._*
-keep public class \* extends android.app.Fragment

-keepattributes EnclosingMethod, InnerClasses
-keepattributes _Annotation_
-keepattributes Signature

. This problem is not holoeverywhere. You need to configure proguard.
For example, add the following:

-keep class android.*\* { _; }
-keep class android.support.v4._\* { _; }
-keep public class \* extends android.support.v4._*
-keep public class \* extends android.app.Fragment

-keepattributes EnclosingMethod, InnerClasses
-keepattributes _Annotation_
-keepattributes Signature

-keep class \* extends android.support.v4.view.*\* { _; }
-keep class \* extends android.widget._\* { _; }
-keep class \* extends android.preference._\* { *; }

etc...

roboto_condensed.ttf

I solved the issue! Here is the style which works. I had to copy a lot of things to get real AlertDialog behavior.

```
<style name="AlertDialog.AppTheme" parent="@style/Holo.AlertDialog">
      <item name="alertDialogTitleDividerColor">@color/AppRed</item>
      <item name="android:windowTitleStyle">@style/DialogWindowTitle.AppTheme</item>
      <item name="borderlessButtonStyle">@style/Button.Borderless.Small.AppTheme</item>
      <item name="android:windowBackground">@android:color/transparent</item>
      <item name="android:colorBackgroundCacheHint">@null</item>
      <item name="android:windowAnimationStyle">@style/Holo.Animation.Dialog</item>
      <item name="android:windowContentOverlay">@null</item>
      <item name="android:windowFrame">@null</item>
      <item name="android:windowIsFloating">true</item>
      <item name="android:windowSoftInputMode">stateUnspecified|adjustPan</item>
      <item name="buttonBarStyle">@style/Holo.ButtonBar.AlertDialog</item>
      <item name="listPreferredItemPaddingLeft">16dip</item>
      <item name="listPreferredItemPaddingRight">16dip</item>
      <item name="windowActionBar">false</item>
      <item name="windowActionModeOverlay">true</item>
      <item name="windowAnimationStyle">@style/Holo.Animation.Dialog</item>
      <item name="windowContentOverlay">@null</item>
      <item name="windowMinWidthMajor">@dimen/dialog_min_width_major</item>
      <item name="windowMinWidthMinor">@dimen/dialog_min_width_minor</item>
      <item name="windowNoTitle">true</item>

  </style>
```
. I know this is a closed issue, but i do not know a better place to ask. Is this the intended usage? Is there a better way to achieve this? Thanks!

. The reason being that it is the official support one, it functions similarly to ActionBarSherlock and gives the functionality expected of the ActionBar in Android 3.0+ . Earlier versions of Android don't support Holo theme still, so this library being coupled with ActionBarSherlock instead of support.v7 now becomes the setback. ABS doesn't play nice with support.v7 in the same project/workspace because they redefine the same attributes.

davidp3:
I just found this bug as I was going to enter one of my own.  I have not yet checked the 'abc' branch... I've been trying to build 'master', which is currently fubar (as you mentioned in another bug related to this).  I will check 'abc'.

The OP is correct.  The problem appears to be related to bug #469.  Apparently, TabSwipeActivity was fixed on Jun 13th and then broken again by a Jun 17th checkin that introduced the AddonTabber stuff.  This appears in the latest release.  The TabSwipeActivity in that version never calls onHandleTabs().  It doesn't help to move the addTab() calls from onHandleTabs() to, say, onCreate, because this produces an error about not being able to add the addon after the Activity was init-ed.  So the window is blank (no tab bar or tab fragments). 
. Update: The abc branch seems to have been abandoned...
. OK, I've got a super-cheap workaround for anyone who had the same issue.  The deal is that AddonTabber is not constructed before onCreate(), as the framework seems to expect.  But you can get there without touching the HoloEverywhere code.  Just create a (parameterless) constructor for your TabSwipeActivity subclass (or your TabSwipeFragment subclass... although I don't know if that one is broken).  In the constructor, call:
`addonTabber()`.  That's it!  This will register the class and then your tabs will appear.
. I'd do that but I can't get trunk to build (not in Eclipse or on command line).  The code has moved on (a lot) from the latest release so I don't even know if the issue is still there.  I'll set up a pull request once I can build and test it.

alexey-rabets:
It seems that ListenerWrapper from _SharedPreferencesImpl_XML.java has no strong references on it, only weak ones. So, the garbage collector destroys it at some moment and the listener disappear. You can easily reproduce this if add System.gc() call right after registerOnSharedPreferenceChangeListener().
. It seems that ListenerWrapper from _SharedPreferencesImpl_XML.java has no strong references on it, only weak ones. So, the garbage collector destroys it at some moment and the listener disappear. You can easily reproduce this if add System.gc() call right after registerOnSharedPreferenceChangeListener().

ASemeniuk:
I had exactly the same problem recently (with exactly the same message). It occurrs only on Android 4.4 devices so it is hard to track down.
After lots of researching I found the reason for this. I was using sliding navigation drawer and the problem was in the following code:

``` java
new ActionBarDrawerToggle(this, mDrawerLayout, a2.getResourceId(0, -1), -1, -1)  {...}
```

The last two parameters stand for content description resources of opened and closed drawer images (accessibility-related stuff). I mistakenly put **-1** there (in order to use default `resID`) but the correct value should be **0** instead.

Hope this helps.
. I had exactly the same problem recently (with exactly the same message). It occurrs only on Android 4.4 devices so it is hard to track down.
After lots of researching I found the reason for this. I was using sliding navigation drawer and the problem was in the following code:

``` java
new ActionBarDrawerToggle(this, mDrawerLayout, a2.getResourceId(0, -1), -1, -1)  {...}
```

The last two parameters stand for content description resources of opened and closed drawer images (accessibility-related stuff). I mistakenly put **-1** there (in order to use default `resID`) but the correct value should be **0** instead.

Hope this helps.

``` java
ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);
ThemeManager.map(ThemeManager.MIXED, R.style.AppBaseTheme);
```

But this crashes on API 19 with this messsage:

```
android.support.v4.app._HoloActivity$HoloThemeException: You must apply Holo.Theme, Holo.Theme.Light or Holo.Theme.Light.DarkActionBar theme on the activity (RouterListActivity) for using HoloEverywhere

ThemeManager.setDefaultTheme(ThemeManager.MIXED);

. Here you go - http://developer.android.com/about/versions/android-4.4.html#UI

Translucent system bars

You can now make the system bars partially translucent with new themes, Theme.Holo.NoActionBar.TranslucentDecor and Theme.Holo.Light.NoActionBar.TranslucentDecor. By enabling translucent system bars, your layout will fill the area behind the system bars, so you must also enable fitsSystemWindows for the portion of your layout that should not be covered by the system bars.

If you're creating a custom theme, set one of these themes as the parent theme or include the windowTranslucentNavigation and windowTranslucentStatus style properties in your theme.
